dialogues.speaker: MAN'S FOOTPRINT
dialogues.text: on the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera begins to pull back slowly, straight up - the song "Moon Shadow" by Cat Stevens begins.  Once we are high enough to see the entire moon, the main title is superimposed. An American Werewolf in London We continue to retreat from the moon, looking on as it grows farther from us, continuing credits until the full moon is the size it appears to us from earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tree branches enter into the frame, the camera pans down and we see a truck approaching.  We are at a crossroads in the moors, looking sinister enough to have earned their literary reputation. The truck stops at the crossroads, the DRIVER, mustached and wearing tweeds, boots, and a muffler, climbs down. "Moon Shadow" ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud bang of the back grating on the truck as it slams down.  Revealed among the sheep are two rudely-awakened young American boys.  They look exhausted.  They both carry backpacks, two American kids on a jaunt in Europe.  They are both in their late twenties. It is very cold and they clamber out of the truck none too happily.  Pushing sheep aside they step out and stretch.

dialogues.speaker: JACK GOODMAN AND DAVID KESSLER
dialogues.text: They've been cramped for hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, lads, East Proctor and all about are the moors.  I go east here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well thank you very much for the ride, sir.  You have lovely sheep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he clambers back up on his truck)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, keep off the moors. Stay on the road.  Good luck to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks again! He drives off.  LONG SHOT of the two boys as the lorry pulls away.  Surrounding them are the moors.  They put on their packs, David points to the signpost pointing towards East Proctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk, their breath visible:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you cold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. They walk on, finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not having a good time are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know.  I mean look around.  Isn't this a fun place? The camera shows us the moors - desolate, cold, foreboding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I like it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  Northern England first, Italy later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. They walk on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think she'll meet me in Rome?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Debbie Klein is a mediocre person with a good body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie is not mediocre and she has one of the great bodies of all time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a jerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking about the woman I love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about a girl you want to fuck, so give me a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, anyway, do you think she'll be there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like an announcer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rendezvous in Rome starring Jack Goodman and Debbie Klein. The love affair that shocked Europe!  See torrid lovemaking at its most explicit!  See Jack and Debbie expose their lust in the sacred halls of the Vatican!  Never has the screen dared....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't stop, I'm going to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to make love to her. It's very simple.  She has no choice really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just fascinates me that you can spend so much energy on someone so dull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is impossible for a body like that to be dull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've known Debbie what, since the eighth grade?  How many years of foreplay is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says she `likes me too much'. David just laughs and laughs and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Jack entering East Proctor.  It is brightly moonlit.  East Proctor consists of a few shops, all closed, a petrol pump and a pub.  East Proctor has a very small population and the place looks empty.  David and Jack enter the middle of town and look about.  The camera sees what they see.  A few shops, dark and shuttered.  Light and laughter come from the pub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its traditional shingle shows a ferocious wolf's bloody head on a pike, and tells us the pub's name, "The Slaughtered Lamb".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Slaughtered Lamb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, The Slaughtered Lamb.  Why else would they have a severed fox head on a spear as their symbol?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a wolf's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, The Slaughtered Lamb.  Why else would they have a severed wolf's head on a spear as their symbol?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a spear.  It's a pike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A severed wolf's head on a pike as their symbol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, before we go in there I want you to know that - no matter what happens to us - it's your fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assume full responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pub was apparently "modernized" sometime in the mid- fifties.  Its traditional Englishness combines with greasy stainless steel and glass.  It is populated by mostly pale young men with longish hair.  Several older men are ruddy complexioned and sport large mustaches. Four or five are watching a chess game.  Two men are playing darts.  The conversation is loud and there is often laughter.  But there is something unsavory about these people.  A look of leanness and poverty.  They seem inbred and somehow sullen.  We establish the types and the general level of noise in the room. The door opens revealing David and Jack.  There is dead silence and all are staring in a not friendly way at the two boys who are made uncomfortable by all the strange attention.  They give each other a "what?" look, then turn to the assembled populace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: FACES
dialogues.text: Silent and staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very cold outside.  May we come in? The WOMAN BARKEEP nods.  The boys walk carefully over to a table and very self-consciously remove their packs, place them on the floor, and sit down at the table.  There is a long, awkward wait.  The Woman finally comes over to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any hot soup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, do you have any coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot chocolate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got spirits and beer. If it's something hot you want, you can have tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you have some hot tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can heat some up for you if you'd like. DAVID & JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, please. As the Woman turns to prepare the tea, everyone resumes what they were doing; talking, drinking, playing chess and darts, and the boys breathe easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice looking group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, at least it's warm in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the wall is painted a red pentangle (a five-pointed star) and on either side burns a yellow candle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a five-pointed star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the owners are from Texas. The Woman brings them their tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Woman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember the Alamo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was joking.  Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joking?  I remember The Alamo. I saw it once in London, in Leicester Square. Jack and David look startled.  One of the CHESS PLAYERS explains:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She means in the cinema, that film with John Wayne. (turns to board)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checkmate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, with Laurence Harvey and everybody died in it.  It was very bloody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody awful if you ask me! This sends everyone into gales of laughter.  Jack and David smile politely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, Gladys, Tom.  Did you hear the one about the crashing plane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but we're about to. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You be quiet, woman, and let me speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heavy sarcasm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet, everyone!  Hush!  Shhh! Uproarious laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, laugh then.  I shan't tell it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, tell us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You've had your chance. The men all coax him to tell the joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to David)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask them what the candles are for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ask them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to David)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, that's a pentangle, a five-pointed star.  It's used in witchcraft.  Lon Chaney, Jr. and Universal Studios maintain it's the mark of the wolf man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.  You want me to ask these people if they're burning candles to ward off monsters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to David)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong. The drinkers have gotten the Chess Player to tell the joke as everyone knew he would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, all right.  There was this airplane over the Atlantic on its way to New York.  It was full of men from the United Nations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very funny, that is. Uproarious laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to David)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, ask them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ask them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here now, let me finish!  So halfway over the ocean the engines run low on petrol so they have to lighten the plane.  So they heave out all the baggage, but it's still too heavy.  So they chuck out the seats, but it's still too heavy!  Finally this Froggy steps up and shouts "Viva la France" and leaps out.  Then an Englishman....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear!  Hear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (undaunted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...steps up and shouts `God save the Queen!' and leaps out.  But the plane is still too heavy.  So the Yank delegate from Texas steps up, shouts, `Remember the Alamo!' and chucks out the Mexican. This is apparently the funniest joke the inhabitants of East Proctor have ever heard.  The laughter is uproarious, choking, knee-slapping, incredible.  As the Chess Player goes to take a drink of beer, the Dart Player gasps out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember the Alamo! ...causing the Chess Player to spit out his beer causing even harder laughter.  Complete hilarity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but what's that star on the wall for? Dead silence.  A dart lands in the wall.  David and Jack are understandably bewildered.  The villagers look hard indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've made me miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never missed the board before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, we'd better go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  I'm starving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no food here. The villagers look threatening and David's voice is a bit urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Jack, shall we go?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently so. The boys pick up their backpacks and move uncertainly for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to men)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't let them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do we owe you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, lads.  Go, God be with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!  You just can't let them go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go!  And stay on the road. Keep clear of the moors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, thanks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beware the moon, lads! David pushes Jack out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is very cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell was that all about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Let's see if there's an inn or something up the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beware the moon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, I'm freezing. They start up the road into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't let them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should the world know our business?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's murder then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then murder it is!  It's in God's hands now. The wax drips from the Pentangle's candles onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: walking on the road surrounded by darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was weird.  I guess leaving was the best idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Now that we're out here and it's three degrees, I'm not so sure I wouldn't rather face a blood- thirsty mob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, not quite a blood- thirsty mob. They keep walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think was wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe that pentangle was for something supernatural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see and they were too embarrassed to talk about it, because they felt so silly. There is a flash of lightning that sends a ghostly illuminating sheet of light over the boys' faces.  The clap of thunder follows loud and rumbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't rain. Downpour.  The boys are walking in a deluge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. They walk getting soaked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, David....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm well aware of how pleasant the weather is in Rome at the present time thank you. Jack spreads his arms and sings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santa Lucia...Santa Lucia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain is loud on the roof and beating on the windows.  The gathered continue to drink, play chess and darts, but all are silent and contemplative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps they'll be safe in the rain. The Chess Player slams his hand on the table.  Shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one brought them here!  No one wanted them here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have told them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you daft?  What do you think they'd say?  They'd think us mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen! The rain is subsiding.  There is a very faint howl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear it?  We must go to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor I. The camera lingers as the Chess Player's hard face shows the man's struggle.  Another howl.  The Chess Player turns suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Jack are now completely out of sight from East Proctor surrounded by darkness and wet.  There is a light drizzle.  They are standing, listening.  The drizzle stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it? David begins to walk, Jack with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be a lot of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A coyote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There aren't any coyotes in England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hound of the Baskervilles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pecos Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heathcliffe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heathcliffe didn't howl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but he was on the moors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a full moon, `beware the moon'. Another howl, this one long and loud.  It is a very inhuman noise, terrifying, and closer this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I vote we go back to The Slaughtered Lamb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. They are both visibly worried and walk briskly back from where they just came.  Although after a bit of fast walking they are getting nowhere.  They stop out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're lost. Another bloodcurdling howl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!  David, what is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anywhere!  I think we should just keep moving. A growl.  A low guttural growl comes from out of the darkness.  We stay on the boys, but we hear something out there.  It starts to walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's circling us. And indeed it is.  The boys strain to hear its four footfalls and they turn slowly, following it.  A snarl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. We hear the wolf-monster stop (for that's what it is - we know it's there even though we've not seen it).  It sits breathing heavily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the plan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not too relaxed himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just keep walking. They do and David keeps talking as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, a lovely stroll in the moors.  Tra-la-la, isn't this fun? The thing stalking them seems to speed up.  The boys hesitate as they sense it run past them.  It stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in front of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think it's a dog? Jack and David strain to see what waits ahead of them. BOYS' P.O.V. Something is waiting in the darkness.  Its hulking shape is barely discernible, but its eyes glow eerily and its breath is visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit.  What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sheep dog or something. Turn slowly and let's walk away. The boys keep talking as they move faster and faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice doggie.  Good boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk away, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking away, yes, sir.  Here we are walking away. They are in a full-out run by now.  After a few minutes flight they stop, panting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. A moment of quiet, then a howl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not far enough.  Come on. They walk briskly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you when we get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  I'm glad we...WHOAA!! David shouts as he slips suddenly in the mud, scaring Jack, and us, and himself a great deal.  He lays startled on the wet ground for a moment, then he and Jack laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really scared me, you shithead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to help me up? Jack takes David's extended hand to help him up when

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lunging beast brings Jack down in one fell swoop. David falls back on his ass.  Jack is screaming and struggling as he is torn to shreds.  David scrambles to his feet and runs in complete panic.  Jack's screams and the wolf's roars combine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus fuck!  David!  Please help me!  Please!  David! Shit!  Help me!  Oh God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David runs and runs.  Finally he falls, out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack?  Oh my God, Jack! He gets up and runs back to find Jack a torn and bloody mess on the ground.  He stares in horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack....

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: THE WOLF SPRINGS!  The camera adopts David's P.O.V. as he fights the dark savage shape on top of him.  Fangs clamp down on his shoulder when shots ring out and the hulking form rolls off of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, dazed and bloody, looks and sees the men from The Slaughtered Lamb armed with shotguns and torches running towards him.  Looking over at his attacker, instead of a wolf he sees a very old, naked man laying in the mud riddled with bullet holes.  As the villagers crowd around, David falls back and faints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is in a small, clean and very white hospital room.  He lays on his back in bed, his shoulder bandaged and his arm plugged into a bottle of plasma. There are several cuts and abrasions on his arms and face, but he really doesn't look too bad.  He opens his eyes slowly, blinks, and tries to sit up and look around, but is unable to because of the pain.  He calls out....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack?! ...and passes out.  However his shout has fetched a nurse.  She is ALEX PRICE, very English, very beautiful.  She goes to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kessler? She looks into his eyes, lifting the lids with her thumb, and then checks his chart at the end of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kessler? David remains unconscious.  Another young nurse, MISS GALLAGHER, comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I should think.  He called out just now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's an American, you know. Dr. Hirsch is going to fetch round one of those Embassy fellows to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chart says he's from New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's a Jew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why on earth do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I looked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, Susan, I don't think that was very proper, and besides, it's common practice now. A voice startles the girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Gallagher, Miss Price is quite right. DR. HIRSCH enters.  He is an older man wearing the customary lab coat.  A very commanding and reassuring presence.  The girls are embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hirsch, Mr. Kessler cried out a minute ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Gallagher, surely you must perform some function here at the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then get on with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Doctor. She exits.  Dr. Hirsch begins to examine David.  Alex watches.  Dr. Hirsch turns to Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I be of service, Miss Price?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hirsch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go about your duties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Doctor. She starts to exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Miss Price?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly did he call out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said `Jack'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be Jack Goodman, the boy who was killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police report said an escaped lunatic attacked them. He must have been a very powerful man.  Although I really don't see that it is any of your concern, Miss Price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.  Of course, sir. Good day, Doctor. She exits as Dr. Hirsch continues his examination, looking into David's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera is handheld, running furiously through the almost dense greenery.  On the soundtrack are the footfalls and heavy breathing of the runner.  The camera abruptly stops and turns, sharply looking about, the panting continuing.  The breathing gets louder and harder, then too loud when we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David opens his eyes quickly, the silence and whiteness contrast sharply with the preceding fantasy.  Standing beside the bed are Dr. Hirsch and MR. COLLINS.  Mr. Collins wears a bow tie and is holding a briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, David.  I am Dr. Hirsch and this is a countryman of yours, Mr. Collins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in a hospital in London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: London?  Where's Jack?  I had a strange dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should think so after your recent traumatic experiences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy I was with.  Is he all right?  How did I get to London?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, David, I want you to prepare yourself; your friend is dead. David jolts up in bed and shouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? The sudden exertion and strain hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow, shit! He sinks back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kessler, I am Mr. Collins of the American Embassy here in Grosvenor Square.  Both Mr. Goodman's parents and your parents have been notified of your injuries and everything's in order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's in order?  What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Goodman's body has been air-freighted back to New York for burial and your parents have wired funds for your stay in the hospital until you are well enough to fly home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (controlled tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't crate and ship Jack like some side of beef. (approaching hysteria)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you people? What's going on here?  Where is Jack?  I demand to see him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds David down, calls out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Price!  Miss Price, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your fucking hands off me! What the hell is going on here? Alex enters amidst David's shouting and confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distraught, clutching his briefcase)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I realize how upsetting this must be for you, Mr. Kessler, but please try to refrain from hysterics. David continues shouting and struggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prepare a hypodermic, please, Miss Price. The shot is administered and David is held down by Dr. Hirsch and Alex until his breathing becomes more normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Mr. Kessler, try not to excite yourself.  Everything has been arranged.  I shall come back to check on your progress and send a report to your parents.  The police have requested to interview you and I have given them permission to do so. Dr. Hirsch walks Mr. Collins to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, Mr. Collins.  He'll rest now and I'm sure everything will be fine once he's adjusted.  He's had quite a shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These dumb-ass kids never appreciate anything you do for them. Mr. Collins exits.  Dr. Hirsch crosses back to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have I been here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been unconscious since you were brought in two weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two weeks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've suffered some rather severe cuts and bruises, lost a bit of blood, but nothing too serious; black and blue for a while.  You'll have some dueling scars to boast of. That lunatic must have been a very fierce fellow.  They say a mad man has the strength of ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, as the drugs take hold)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunatic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we've just given you a pretty strong sedative, so try to get some rest now.  Miss Price will see to your needs. Rest now. Dr. Hirsch watches as Alex straightens David's covers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't a lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a wolf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bends down close to hear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wolf. David passes out.  Alex looks to Dr. Hirsch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say a wolf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I believe he did. Dr. Hirsch regards David thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hirsch is on the phone, he is referring to a desk calendar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Roger is so terribly boring.  Yes, dear, but couldn't we...I see. (he makes a note)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thursday at eight, dinner with boring Roger.  Yes, I'm sure I will; if I survived Rommel, I suppose I'll survive another excruciating evening with Roger Mathison.  Be a good girl.  Bye. He hangs up very disgruntled.  The intercom buzzes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Villiers and Sgt. McManus are here to see you, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send them in. He rises to greet the two police officers, one tall, the other rather pudgy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hirsch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, come in.  Please sit. Some tea? The cops sit down, Lt. Villiers immediately produces a small notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you. SGT. McMANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like some tea, please. Lt. Villiers shoots the sergeant a withering look. SGT. McMANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe not.  No thanks.  Maybe later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, what can I do for Scotland Yard? SGT. McMANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We understand the Kessler boy has regained consciousness. Lt. Villiers glares at McManus. SGT. McMANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has Mr. Kessler said anything regarding the attack on the moors? The intercom buzzes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.  Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger Mathison, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I'm out.  No, tell him I've passed away.  An old war wound or something.  Tell him I'm dead.  And no more calls! He turns from the intercom back to the cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has David Kessler anything to say concerning the attack on the moors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we ask him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David sits up in bed.  Lt. Villiers and Sgt. McManus stand by his side.  Dr. Hirsch sits observing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if I conflict with your report, but Jack and I were not attacked by a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you've said. SGT. McMANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He may have a point, Lieutenant.  Two strong boys would be able to defend themselves against one man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sgt. McManus, are you suggesting that David and Jack were, in fact, attacked by some animal and that the officialdom of East Proctor has conspired to keep it a secret?  We have an autopsy report on the murderer who was shot in the act by the local police.  We have two witnesses to the crime.  You'll forgive me, Mr. Kessler, if I consider your testimony as coming from someone who has gone through a terrible shock. SGT. McMANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, the boy seems pretty lucid to me and....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what, Sergeant? SGT. McMANUS (defeated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't rightly know, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is precisely my point. David, as far as we are concerned, the matter is closed.  We won't trouble you any further.  Good day. The lieutenant goes for the door.  The sergeant smiles at David and follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor. The cops exit.  Dr. Hirsch crosses to David's bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were witnesses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could there have been witnesses?  It was so dark. We were running and I fell and Jack went to help me up and this thing came from nowhere...I don't understand what they're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In time I'm sure it will all come back to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor, my memory is fine. It's my sanity I'm beginning to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again the handheld camera is running furiously through the woods.  Heavy breathing and the sounds of the runner crashing through the foliage.  The camera runs for a while then suddenly stops short near a tree. David abruptly enters frame, animal-like, the tenseness of a startled cat.  His head makes sudden movements, looking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of his flared nostrils and perked up ears accenting his animalness.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: takes off and now we run with him.  He runs fast and gracefully, taking long strides and leaps.  We run with him faster and faster sharing in his exhilaration.  We see him completely as the animal, study his movement and grace as if watching a gazelle.  Suddenly he stops again, alert, listening.  He moves with stealth, slowly he pushes some leaves aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of his eyes. DAVID'S P.O.V. Several deer in the forest; they sense something and freeze, the camera noting a fawn next to a doe.  The buck turns his head, feeling the danger.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Shots showing the muscles in his legs and shoulders tensing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of David's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of the frightened deer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of David's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: THE FAWN
dialogues.text: as it is leapt upon, its terrified face leaving frame as David forces it down.  David's head reenters frame, his mouth full of flesh, his face and hands covered with blood.  He howls in triumph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are subdued and David's asleep.  The door opens, a shaft of light penetrates the room.  Miss Gallagher enters with a small tray.  She crosses to David, turns on the bed light and touches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kessler?  Wake up, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awakened)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was having a nightmare. Miss Gallagher is very efficient in administering the pills and pouring a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well these should help that.  That's right, drink up. David takes the pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now go back to sleep so you'll be fresh for Dr. Hirsch in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nearly eight.  I'm off duty shortly, then I'm off to the films with Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Price, the other nurse that attended you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An American film about the Mafia called `See You Next Wednesday', and I want to see it badly, so you give me no problems and go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dropping off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have bad dreams, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some, everyone does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but does everyone kill Bambi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bambi? David has fallen asleep.  Miss Gallagher turns off the light, picks up her tray and pauses in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill Bambi? She exits, closing the door plunging the room into darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corridor is busy with orderlies pushing gurneys about, doctors, visitors, and patients all performing appropriate background actions.  Behind the Nurses' Counter, Alex is typing some forms and an older, obviously senior nurse is filling some paper cups with different sizes and colors of pills she is taking from the drug cabinet.  She is MRS. HOBBS, the chief nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mrs. Hobbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take these round now, will you please?  The American boy in twenty-one is only to have these after he's eaten.  Will you be sure of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he been refusing food?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing quite as dramatic as that, Miss Price.  He just doesn't eat enough of what is put before him.  He suffers from nightmares.  I'd think he just needs a hand to hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mrs. Hobbs. Alex takes the cups handed to her and makes her way down the hallway, pausing a moment to straighten her appearance.  She enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ward with seven or eight beds in it, all occupied. She goes to a little Pakistani boy named BENJAMIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Benjamin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, all right then, be that way.  Here, swallow this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Alex pours a glass of water, gives the pill to Benjamin who promptly takes it and then drinks the water, handing Alex back the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feeling better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor will be round later.  Would you like a picture book to look at?  We have some lovely funny Beanos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. She exits, pausing in the hall to speak to a black Jamaican ORDERLY pushing a cart of lunch trays into Benjamin's ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has the patient in twenty-one gotten his tray yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The American?  Yes, duck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did he look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, `how did he look'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, did he seem depressed?  Do you think he'll eat the food?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an orderly, not a bleeding psychiatrist!  I push things about, but I've little say what happens to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Alex holds up her head and proceeds to David's room. She hesitates, then peeks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The curtains are drawn and David's lunch waits patiently on its tray alongside of the bed.  David is apparently asleep.  Alex enters softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kessler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifeless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't eaten your lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not very hungry, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid you have to eat something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, really.  I'm not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You put me in an awkward position, Mr. Kessler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she shakes the paper cup)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're to take these after you've eaten.  Now what kind of nurse would I be if I failed in so simple a task as giving out some pills?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave the pills.  I'll take them later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. She opens the curtains, daylight fills the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw come on, Miss Price!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw come on, Alex!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I be forced to feed you, Mr. Kessler? David is getting interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I be forced to feed you, David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is absurd.  I'm not hungry.  I don't want any food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Alex efficiently removes the covers from the dishes and sits on the edge of the bed.  Taking knife and fork in hand, she neatly cuts David's food into pieces.  David watches all this amused.  She places a napkin under David's chin and holds up his first bite on his fork. David folds his arms and refuses to open his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's try a little harder, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you give me a break? Alex grabs David's nose forcing his mouth open quickly, shoving the fork in it.  David is startled, but amused and chews his food slowly and swallows it.  Alex holds up another bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will I have to take such drastic action again, David? David opens his mouth obediently.  Alex almost smiles. She feeds him for a while; they are both sizing each other up.  Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have a glass of milk? Alex smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again we are running fast and faster.  David again running naked, flying through the green forest.  He stops suddenly, ears perked, he looks about and then we hear Jack's o.s. screams.  The voice of Jack screams:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David!  David!  Please help me!  Oh God!  David!  Oh my God! David turns in blind panic, he runs (and we run with him) desperately trying to find the source of Jack's screams. He comes to a clearing in the woods, light streaming through the tall trees.  Jack's screams halt in mid- word.  David looks in disbelief at the clearing.  There is a hospital bed with someone in it.  It is the same as David's. David walks toward it slowly.  The figure in the bed lays still.  It grows dark, very dark, and David looks up at the full moon.  There is a howl identical to the one heard earlier back on the moors.  David approaches the bed slowly, fearfully.  We hear ocean noises on the soundtrack, the sound of crashing surf.  David reaches out to pull back the covers, lightning and thunder cause him to hesitate for a second.  Silence.  The camera remains on David as he pulls off the covers. His face registers total disbelief and increasing horror. We cut to the bed to find - DAVID.  He lies there, pale white with purple lips and death pallor. The camera begins to move in on the corpse of David. Cut back to the standing David's terrified face; then continue until David's death mask fills the screen. The face remains still for several beats, then suddenly opens its bright yellow eyes and red mouth revealing fangs in a bloodcurdling wail which carries over in the....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hobbs hears David's screams and efficiently calls out....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orderly!  Miss Gallagher! Miss Gallagher and an ORDERLY appear at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orderly, go at once to twenty- one and restrain the patient. The orderly exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Gallagher, remain here at the desk.  I'll be in twenty- one. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is bright, daylight, and Dr. Hirsch gazes thoughtfully out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never had bad dreams before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (upset)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, as a kid.  But never so real.  Never so bizarre. Dr. Hirsch crosses over and sits on a chair by the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get a good look at the man who attacked you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've told you, it wasn't a man.  It was an animal.  A big wolf or something.  A rabid dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chewing on his glasses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Dr. Hirsch, I know I've been traumatized, but Jack was torn apart.  I saw him.  A man can't do that to someone with his bare hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised what horrors a man is capable of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  In fact, your wounds were cleaned and dressed before you arrived here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you talk to the police in East Proctor?  Did the cops go to The Slaughtered Lamb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why the hell are you so quick to disbelieve me?  You yourself said it must have taken incredible strength to tear apart a person like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rubs his forehead)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, please.  The police are satisfied.  I'm certain that if a monster were out roaming northern England we'd have seen it on the telly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think I'm crazy, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me.  The Hound of the Baskervilles was an invention of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's. And if you'd read the bloody book, you'd find that Holmes discovered your house of hell a fraud, a fake. There is an awkward silence as David sits and Dr. Hirsch is embarrassed at raising his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now really, David.  You're far too intelligent to go on this way.  When you return to America I want you to seek out a competent psychiatrist or psychologist or something and stop this nonsense.  You'll be leaving this hospital in three or four days, please remain sane.  At least until you are no longer our responsibility. Dr. Hirsch goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hirsch? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather not be by myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not, David.  I'll fetch in young Miss Price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex sits next to David's bed.  Her shoes are off and she has her feet tucked up under her legs on the chair. The room is dark except for the lamp by which she reads.  She is reading A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court by Mark Twain.  David is asleep.  Alex reads for a bit, then puts down the book and yawns. She gets up and stretches, a big spreading arms and feet, fingers and toes stretch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a very beautiful girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was.  What are you reading?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court' by Mark Twain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just started it.  My friend gave it to me. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you dream about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dream of death mostly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  I shouldn't have asked you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.  I want to talk to you. They sit and look at each other for a while longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not really a very proper question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm twenty-seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what do you want to talk about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was Jack Goodman your good friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seriously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My best friend.  My very best friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I read to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Oh, yes, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opens book)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court by Samuel L. Clemens.  This is after the preface but before chapter one: A Word of Explanation. You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (settles back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clears her throat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahem, A Word of Explanation. It was in Warwick Castle that I came across the curious stranger whom I am going to talk about.  He attracted me by three things: his candid simplicity, his marvelous familiarity with ancient armor, and the restfulness of his company - for he did all the talking.  We fell together as modest people will in the tail of the herd....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are at David's parents' house in New York.  His FATHER sits reading the paper in the living room as his younger BROTHER and SISTER watch "The Muppet Show" on television.  We can see past the small dining nook where David sits doing homework and into the kitchen where his MOTHER is washing the dishes.  A peaceful lower, middle class setting.  All is tranquil and secure.  There is a loud pounding on the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it. The pounding continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right!  Hold your horses. (The following happens with shocking speed.)  When he opens the door, four beings open fire with machine guns, blowing him away.  The sudden burst of violence is terrifying and unrelenting.  The four rush into the room and the family looks at them in fearsome surprise for these men are not human at all, but loathsome, bestial demons dressed as Storm Troopers.  One kicks in the television and fires into the kitchen, blasting David's mother.  David rises but is forced back into his chair by one of the things and held there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! He watches in horror as his little brother and sister scream in terror before they are brutally murdered. The monstrous Storm Troopers then set fire to the rooms.  The one holding David pulls a knife and quickly slits David's throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David bolts upright in bed and looks around, trying desperately to gain his bearings.  He sees that Alex is asleep in the chair by his bed, Connecticut Yankee folded on her lap.  He makes a deliberate effort to calm himself.  He considers waking her, then decides against it.  He turns on the lamp by his bed and reaches over to take the book from Alex's lap.  David takes the book as gently as possible, but Alex wakes up anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yawns, smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.  You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I woke you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly.  Can I get you something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.  Just keep me company for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's easy enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep having these really terrible dreams.  They are getting worse and I can't seem to stop them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, your dreams will stop. You'll leave England and your bad memories; and then this will all fade away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you come with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious.  You don't know me and I know nothing about you.  We have a perfect relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, David, I said I would keep you company, but I meant right here and now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you think about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did we get from your bad dreams to my taking a holiday with a patient?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big grin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not just a patient -- me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're being awfully forward, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, I'm trying to cheer myself up and an affair with a beautiful nurse seemed like just the thing to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I am to you is a sex fantasy then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  I thought for a moment I was the only embarrassed one in the room. There is an awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were we in the book? Alex is relieved for something to break the tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking through the book)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black Orderly hustles in with David's breakfast tray, busily setting up the tray on the table over the bed.  He awakens the sleeping David with his activity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah you're up.  Good morning and a good day to you.  We've quite a meal for you here this morning.  Bacon, oatmeal, orange juice, and toast with jam.  Good stuff there.  Now eat it up and I'll be back for the dishes when you've finished. The Orderly exits.  The drowsy David, who has been trying to fully wake up during the Orderly's speech, notices his exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning. He looks at his food none too happily.  He sticks a spoon into the bowl of oatmeal and tastes is gingerly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in mock English accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, sir, I want some more. He settles down to eating, reaches over to butter his toast and drink his juice.  While he eats, we hear Jack's o.s. voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have a piece of toast? David looks over to the o.s. Jack.  Jack, behaving relaxed and normal, sits in the chair last occupied by Alex.  However, Jack's appearance makes his casual manner all the more surreal.  He is as we left him butchered on the moors.  He is covered with dried mud and open wounds.  Huge glistening gashes abound on his body.  His face is scratched, his throat is badly torn, and his hair is matted with blood.  In several spots he has already begun to rot.  He is a remarkably gruesome sight, but his physical state seems not to affect him at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unbelieving)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the fuck out of here, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is too much.  I can't handle this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm aware that I don't look so great, but I thought you'd be glad to see me. Jack gets up and takes a piece of toast from David's tray as David watches amazed.  Jack returns to his seat and takes a bite out of his toast.  David stares at Jack horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David!  You're hurting my feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (astounded)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurting your feelings?  Has it occurred to you that it may be unsettling to have you rise from your grave to visit me? Listen to me, I'm talking to a hamburger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to be upsetting you, David, but I had to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aghast)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you supposed to be buried in New York someplace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Your parents came to my funeral.  I was surprised at how many people came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resigned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should you be surprised? You were a very well-liked person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie Klein cried a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stand it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you know what she does? She's so grief stricken she runs to find solace in Rudy Levine's bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy Levine the shmuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life mocks me even in death. Jack takes another bite of toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going completely crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, now I know this may be hard for you, but I have to warn you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warn me?  Will you get out of here, you meat loaf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a grisly sight, it's true; but I love you and that's why I'm here.  You've got to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you love me so much, Jack, you'll realize how disconcerting it is to share one's breakfast with the living dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were attacked by a werewolf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covers his ears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not listening!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the moors, we were attacked by a lycanthrope, a werewolf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, you zombie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was murdered, an unnatural death, and now I walk the earth in limbo until the werewolf's curse is lifted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous, furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you?  Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wolf's bloodline must be severed.  The last remaining werewolf must be destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be quiet?! Jack rises and comes closer to David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's you, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You survived and now you shall continue the curse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?  I won't accept this!  Get out! God damit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember what that guy at The Slaughtered Lamb said? `Beware the moon.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beware the moon.  The full moon, David.  You've got two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, please go away.  Please go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll stalk the streets of London a creature of the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flares up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking like Boris Karloff!  It's movie dialogue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, please believe me.  You will kill people, David. You've got to stop the bloodshed before it begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me!  Take your own life, David.  It's our only chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The supernatural!  The powers of darkness!  It's all true. Take your own life!  Suicide, David.  Join me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (losing it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse!  Oh God!  Alex!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cold, David, and I'm so alone.  The undead surround me.  Have you ever talked to a corpse?  It's boring!  I'm lonely!  Kill yourself, David, before you kill others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex rushing down the hospital corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David rocking back and forth weeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't cry, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex rushing down hospital corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex rushing to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly in looming closeup)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beware the moon, David.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: as she bursts into the room.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: laying in bed rocking from side to side, crying softly. He is alone.  Alex rushes over, removes the tray, sits on the bed and hugs David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David?  David! David pulls away sharply, his head jerking about wildly until he focuses on Alex's face and begins to breathe easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, what's wrong? David smiles and kisses her, a real kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a werewolf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A werewolf? Alex holds David a moment then realizes where she is and backs off a little.  David composes himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you better now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll let you know the next full moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're to be discharged tomorrow.  Will you be all right? David takes Alex's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend Jack was just here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your dead friend Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  He says that I will become a monster in two days. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I think?  You mean about the possibility of your becoming a monster in two days or about visits from dead friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was dreaming again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resigned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I would think so, too. Alex considers for a while, finally....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a place to stay in London?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Alex walking down the street.  Alex points out her flat and leads David up the front steps.  She gives him a conspiratorial look and unlocks the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex enters and David follows.  A small, utilitarian apartment, she flicks on the kitchen light.  David puts his backpack on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very nice. She proceeds to give the tour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is only one bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (makes a face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, perhaps you'd like to watch the telly while I take a shower. Alex enters the room and David whistles softly, rocking on his heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Alex stand facing each other under the stream of water in the shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: SHOWER
dialogues.text: A sequence of soap and flesh.  Van Morrison's "Moondance" plays.  A montage of soapy hands on slippery skin.  Thighs rubbing thighs, arms and shoulders.  David and Alex kiss again and again and....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Alex in a passionate, orgasmic kiss in Alex's bed.  David pulls out and they lay holding each other. After a moment....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be here in about fifteen minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Alex props herself up on one elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, you don't honestly believe that in reality your friend Jack rose from the grave to breakfast with you? Do you really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was awake and he was in my room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't hallucinating. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow is the full moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good, Alex.  Reassure me. Alex begins kissing David's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, I know I'm being insane. She kisses his shoulders, then his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay.  I'm properly reassured! Alex is now kissing his stomach, her head gradually lowers from frame.  David reaches back over his head to hold onto the headboard of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (closing his eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is very reassuring.  I'm feeling very reassured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is asleep holding David.  David carefully lifts her arm and gets out of bed.  He is naked.  He tiptoes out of the room and goes to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David lifts the toilet seat and pees.  He winces, hoping the steady stream doesn't awaken Alex.  When he's finished peeing he goes to the sink.  The medicine cabinet door over the sink is open.  When David closes it he (and the audience) is terrified to see Jack reflected standing behind him.  (Note: This is a big scare.)  Bloodied and horrible, Jack has continued to rot and looks even worse than when we last saw him. David chokes out a strangled cry, closes his eyes tightly and then reopens them.  Jack is still there in the mirror.  When David turns around Jack is standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points a trembling finger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be an asshole, David. Come here. David, clearly troubled, follows Jack into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits down and motions for David to sit also.  He does.  David's conversation is in whispers, so as not to wake up Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you've seen me.  Now go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, I'm sorry I upset you yesterday, but you must understand what is going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand all right. You're one of the undead and I'm a werewolf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here, Jack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, tomorrow night is the full moon.  You'll change, you'll become....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A monster.  I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must take your own life now, David, before it's too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, are you really dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I've lost my mind.  I think you're not real.  I think I'm asleep and you're a part of another bad dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, Jack?  That tomorrow night beneath the full moon I'll sprout hair and fangs and eat people?  Bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The canines will be real. You'll taste real blood!  God damit, David, please believe me!  You'll kill and make others like me!  I'm not having a nice time, David! Don't allow this to happen again!  You must take your own life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not accept this!  Now go away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex wakes up from the shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not pretend, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (righteous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not be threatened by a walking meat loaf! Alex enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, what's wrong?  I heard voices. David turns and sees that Jack is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (triumphant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just me, Alex.  It was just me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hirsch is driving down the main street in his red M.G.  He parks in front of The Slaughtered Lamb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pub is less crowded than when we were here last. The Dart Player is behind the bar cleaning glasses, the Chess Player is still at the chessboard.  Dr. Hirsch enters and crosses to the bar.  As he removes his gloves:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drink for a very cold man? The Woman comes in from the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, there.  What can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campari and soda would do nicely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose Guinness will suffice. She serves him his beer.  As he lays down his money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand thanks. After a few sips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nasty bit of business with those two young American boys. The Dart Player stops his wiping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I don't know what you mean, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm sure that's right.  A few weeks ago, the last full moon wasn't it? The Chess Player turns in his chair to get a good look at Dr. Hirsch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean that escaped lunatic. The one that killed the boy. Wasn't that near here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where are you from, sir? Dr. Hirsch crosses and joins the Chess Player at his table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: London.  Knight takes pawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Sees that Dr. Hirsch was talking about his game....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, yes. Dr. Hirsch points to the pentangle on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's been there for two hundred years.  We were going to paint it out, but it's traditional, so we left it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.  You've heard nothing about the incident?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incident?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The murder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a police officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, hardly.  I work in the hospital where the Kessler boy was brought. The Dart Player and Chess Player exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
