dialogues.text: He was talking about werewolves and monsters and as I was near here I thought....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd look into the boy's story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scoffs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A story about werewolves - now really, sir. Dr. Hirsch eyes the Chess Player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like a game of chess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find Alex and David in an embrace by the front door. Alex is dressed in her nurse's uniform and David has jeans and a T-shirt on.  He is shoeless and obviously not going out.  Alex pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go now, you'll make me late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me an enormous favor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me that it's silly of me to be apprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's silly of you to be apprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Werewolves simply do not exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, do you want me to stay here tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do, but go to work. He opens the door and they both go outside.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: walk to the sidewalk.  It is rather chilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, if you get too anxious, call me at the hospital, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've left those pills for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A doper werewolf. They kiss again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm off.  There's food in the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you later. Alex goes off, turning for a last wave.  David stands looking after her when a LITTLE GIRL walking a dog passes by.  The dog, on seeing David, begins to growl and snarl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to dog)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I do? The dog begins barking ferociously, the little girl tugging on his leash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot, dog. He realizes just how cold he is outside and runs back up the steps to find the door locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful. Cut to shot of David's bare feet on the cold stone.  He mutters to himself, imitating a newscaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An American werewolf was found frozen to death today in the heart of London, England. He looks around and sees that there is a small window ajar on the side of the flat about eleven feet off the ground, which can be reached by climbing a brick wall, which he does but not without damage to his bare toes. At the top of the wall is a cat that begins to hiss on seeing David.  The hair stands up on its arched back and it glares at David, hissing and spitting.  David is disturbed by the cat's hostile behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I do, cat? The cat is really acting fierce.  When David goes to pat it cautiously, it screeches and runs away.  David is, by this time, not amused.  David manages to pull himself into the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David awkwardly enters the bathroom through the tiny window.  Finally getting both feet on the ground, he steps to the sink and regards himself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snarl.  Growl.  Grrrr. He examines his mouth, touching his canines carefully. After a while he sighs and goes into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David goes straight to the fridge and opens it.  He closes the fridge and walks into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lays down on the bed.  After a few beats of staring at the ceiling, he rises and goes back into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reopens the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not hungry. He closes the fridge and walks into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David turns on the television.  On Thames is a soccer match.  On BBC 1 is some truly insipid children's program, and on BBC 2 is a soccer match.  David switches off the television. He sits on the chair nervously, drumming his fingers and humming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Moon River, wider than a mile I'm crossing you in style, Someday....' David gets up, goes to the front door, and flings it open.  It is getting dark.  David views this fearfully, but still not completely convinced.  He goes back inside and we note that the front door is not completely closed.  He goes back into the bathroom and looks into the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fee fi fo fum, I smell the blood of an Englishman. He goes back into the living room and paces round and round the room like a caged animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is back with Benjamin, the little Pakistani.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are we feeling tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin, have you ever been severely beaten about the face and neck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought not. She tucks him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sleep now and have sweet dreams. BENJAMIN & ALEX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! For the first time, Benjamin smiles.  As Alex tucks him in, we can clearly see the full moon outside through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David sits reading Connecticut Yankee when he suddenly clutches his head in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! He stands in agony, the book falls to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screams)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Christ!  What? He begins sweating profusely, clinging to the sides of his head.  He trembles violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm burning up!  Jesus! He rips at his shirt, tearing it off.  His body is dripping wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts out in pain and fear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack!?  Where are you now, you fucker!?! As a new spasm of pain wracks his body, he cries out in anguish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me!  Somebody help me, please!  Jack!! David's hair is wringing wet.  He screams and grabs at his legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading, whimpering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I called you a meat loaf, Jack. New bolts of agonizing pain wrack through David's body. He grabs at his pants, pulling them off as if they are burning him. Standing naked in the center of the room, David gasps for air. He falls to his knees and then forward on his hands. He remains on his hands and knees, trying to master his torment; but it's no use.  On all fours he gives himself over to the excruciating hurt and slowly begins to change. The metamorphosis from man into beast is not an easy one.  As bone and muscle bend and reform themselves, the body suffers lacerating pain.  We can actually see David's flesh move, the rearranging tissue.  His mouth bleeds as fangs emerge.  His whole face distorts as his jaw extends, his skull literally changing shape before our eyes.  His hands gnarl and his fingers curl back as claws burst forward. The camera pans up to show the full moon outside through the window.  David's moans change slowly into low guttural growls.  We hear the four footfalls as the WOLF begins to walk.  As the camera pans back over the room, we see the front door pushed open and hear the Wolf padding off into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi pulls up in front of a block of flats.  An attractive couple gets out.  The Man pays the driver and the cab drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one, Harry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number thirty-nine, but let's go `round the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, we'll give Sean a scare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy, Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Harry takes her hand and leads her around the side of the flats.  The apartments back up to a park and the two walk around to the rear.  The park is dark and quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Here we are, Sean's is the one.... THE WOLF SPRINGS!  Before the Woman can scream, the Wolf whirls around and goes for her throat.  We can't see clearly, but we see enough to realize how large the Wolf is and that its wolfen features are twisted and demonic.  The Wolf savagely devours its two victims.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean's wife is looking through their French windows out onto the park - a middle-aged couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean, those hooligans are in the park again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you ready yet?  They'll be here any minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's going on out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Gallagher is helping Mrs. Hobbs dispense medication into paper cups when Dr. Hirsch approaches. He is still wearing his overcoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Miss Price on duty this evening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Gallagher, do you know if Miss Price has seen the Kessler boy since his release? Miss Gallagher is not sure how to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I don't know if.... Alex has walked up and overheard the last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Susan.  Yes, Doctor, I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to my office, Miss Price. Alex and Susan exchange glances as she obediently follows Dr. Hirsch down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean has exited the back of his flat to investigate his wife's complaints.  She hangs by the door.  He walks deeper into the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is anyone there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hirsch hangs up his overcoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Alex. Alex sits and Dr. Hirsch leans against his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in East Proctor today. Alex looks confused.  Dr. Hirsch realizes the cause of her concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear girl, your extracurricular activities are of no consequence to me.  I don't give a damn who you sleep with.  I'm concerned about David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a full moon.  Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At my flat.  I'm off at midnight and.... Dr. Hirsch picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number, Alex.  Your number!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean carefully approaches something near the trees.  He steps on something and looks down to see what it is. It is an arm.

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE
dialogues.text: rings loudly.  (This is a scare.)  It continues to ring unanswered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hirsch waits on the phone, finally hanging up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not there. Alex grows worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex, has David persisted in his werewolf fantasies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes, but he seems to be more upset by the death of his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has his friend appeared to him again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David says Jack comes to warn him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warn him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hirsch, what's wrong?  Is this more serious than I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to investigate the attack.  There are no records. The case was closed and now they've `misplaced' the file. David's lacerations were cleaned and dressed when he arrived here and yet supposedly no doctor examined him before I did.  The Goodman boy is already in the ground so he's no good to us.  So I went to the pub in East Proctor where I was convinced of two things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were lying.  There were no witnesses, no escaped lunatic.  The whole community is hiding the truth of what actually happened up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the village of East Proctor is hiding some dark and terrible secret.  I'm convinced that, like David, they believe in this werewolf. Alex is flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've absolutely no idea where David might be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  He knows no one in London, besides me.  I shouldn't have left him alone. Suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely you're not suggesting....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David has suffered a severe trauma.  I myself witnessed some form of mass neurosis in East Proctor.  If all the villagers believe that Jack Goodman was killed by a werewolf, why shouldn't David? And then it follows that if he survived an attack by a werewolf, wouldn't he himself become a werewolf the next full moon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hirsch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't mean running about on all fours and howling at the moon.  But in such a deranged state he could harm himself, or perhaps others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What shall we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's call the police and see if they can help us find our wandering boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bombed-out ruins of this unsavory part of London are stark and uninviting in the moonlight.  Three old DERELICTS are huddled around a trash can fire trying to keep warm.  A skinny dog is tied up beside them.  Its ears perk up and he growls in warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Winston smells something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's there? The dog begins to whine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let `im go. Derelict #1 unties Winston who takes off running in terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brave dog that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here - who's there? An unearthly howl shatters the night.  We've heard this sound on the moors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not Winston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look there. He points out into the night.  They strain their eyes - something is approaching them.  They can just make out its size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother Mary of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train SCREECHES to a halt.  (A scare.)  We are in the tubes of London.  Only one passenger disembarks and the train goes off, leaving him alone in the cavernous hallways.  The PASSENGER is a young man, rather well- dressed.  He looks about the platform, then at his watch.  He walks up to a vending machine to buy a Cadbury Chocolate Bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Passenger puts his coin in the vending machine. The camera is on ground level and as we watch the Passenger, the Wolf's legs flash by us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of the Passenger eating his chocolate bar.  He turns thoughtfully, wondering if he had heard something. Satisfied that he is alone, he begins his walk down one of the long serpentine tunnels that make up London's tubes.  He feels he's being followed and turns slowly to look.  There is no one and he continues, concerned about his imagination.

dialogues.speaker: WOLF'S EYES
dialogues.text: watching in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Our Passenger approaches the first escalator, pauses, then gets on going swiftly and silently up the moving stairway.

dialogues.speaker: WOLF'S SNOUT
dialogues.text: In profile we can see its ragged, razor-sharp fangs and black tongue.  It waits, panting, drool falls from its mouth.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The Passenger reaches the landing and walks briskly down the long tunnel marked "Escalator to Street Level".  He is being followed.  He hears it and we hear it.  He stops, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: TUNNEL
dialogues.text: Long and empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there someone there? We hear the Wolf's heavy breathing.  The Passenger is beginning to panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can assure you that this is not in the least bit amusing! He looks around wildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall report this! PASSENGER'S P.O.V. We see the Wolf at a great distance trotting down the tunnel towards us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord.

dialogues.speaker: THE PASSENGER
dialogues.text: turns to flee, his jog becoming a run.  He is terrified.

dialogues.speaker: WOLF
dialogues.text: of the Wolf's running steps.

dialogues.speaker: THE PASSENGER
dialogues.text: frantically running, falls to the ground hard bloodying his nose.  He scrambles to his feet crying out in fear. Reaching the escalator, he begins to run up the moving stairs, falling several times.  He sits, panting and defeated, the blood trickling from his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as it begins to climb the stairs.  The camera tracks slowly in on the increasingly horrified Passenger until we are in an extreme closeup of his eyes, when we:

dialogues.speaker: A TIGER ROARING
dialogues.text: (A scare.)  The tiger paces in its cage and roars again.  We are at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is early morning and all the animals are aroused. We cut around to roaring cats, screeching monkeys, and panicky birds, etc., until we come to the Wolves' cage where we find David, naked and curled up on the ground by the cage, asleep.  David wakes up slowly.  He is completely naked, his body dirty, with several scratches on his torso and legs.  He yawns and stretches, makes a face, and with his finger picks something distasteful from his teeth.  He also notices something under his fingernails and as he goes to clean them, he suddenly does a complete Stan Laurel discovering where he is.  He puts his hands over his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake me up, Alex. He slowly peaks through his fingers; he's still there. He stands up and looks around. The zoo opens and women with prams and children hustle about.  David sees them coming towards him, notes his lack of clothes, and decides it would be better for all concerned if they did not meet.  He looks around for a suitable hiding place and dashes behind some bushes. He crouches down so that he can't be seen, scratching himself on a thorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex sits holding David's torn T-shirt.  She is trying to read her book, but is just too distracted.  The phone rings and she runs for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited, then disappointed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?  No, Dr. Hirsch, he hasn't come back yet.  Yes, I will, doctor, but I just feel so helpless sitting here doing nothing.  Thank you, yes, goodbye. She hangs up and looks around the empty flat.  She is now more worried than ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is still behind the bushes.  He looks to see if the coast is clear, then stands up and parts the bushes.  He steps out to confront a DOWAGER LADY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: DOWAGER'S FACE
dialogues.text: Dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, won't you? He returns to the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: A GORILLA EATING
dialogues.text: A LITTLE BOY with four helium balloons on a string is staring intently at the gorilla.  The Little Boy leaves the monkey house and we travel with him as he looks at several other animals.  Eventually he comes to the Wolf cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pssst! The Little Boy looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, kid!  Pssst.  Little boy with the balloons. The Little Boy pantomimes, "who me?"

dialogues.speaker: THE BUSHES
dialogues.text: David cannot be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come over here. The Little Boy shakes his head.  The bush replies:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you come over here, I'll give you a pound. The Little Boy shakes his head.  The bush pleads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two pounds? The Little Boy shakes his head.  The bush reasons:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, two pounds is a lot of money.  It's almost five dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very English)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know who you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the famous balloon thief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would a thief want to give me two pounds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (losing patience)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here and I'll show you. The Little Boy starts cautiously towards the shrubbery, but stops a few feet away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! The Little Boy edges forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little closer. When the Little Boy gets within reach, David grabs his balloons and uses them to cover his crotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. David runs off through the zoo, naked but for his balloons, startling several animal lovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ELDERLY COUPLE sits feeding birds, their coats folded nearly over the park bench.  A naked blur darts by, grabbing the top coat as it passes, scaring off the birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Little Boy tugs at his MOTHER'S coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A naked, American man stole my balloons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A naked, American man -- the famous balloon thief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The signs they always have on London newsstands proclaim "Man or Monster?"  Dr. Hirsch picks up a newspaper with its headline, "London Murder Victims Found Partially Devoured".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have one of those, too. He pays for the papers.  The second one's headline, "Death Toll Up To Six - New Jack The Ripper?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in another part of town.  The camera is on the crowd of fifteen or twenty people waiting for the bus.  When the bus pulls up, they all crowd in.  The camera goes to floor level and slowly examines the footwear of the crowded bus.  Passengers are standing in the aisle and the camera slowly pans on their galoshes, boots, high heels, rubbers, etc., until it comes to rest on a conspicuous pair of bare feet.  We pan up to find David clad only in a woman's rain coat with a fur collar trying to look as nonchalant as possible.  A man looks at him oddly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of weather we've been having lately. The man studies David carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex sits in the kitchen drinking tea and reading. There is loud knocking on the door.  Alex rushes to open it and David enters quickly, closing the door behind him.  He is still wearing the woman's coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David!  Where on earth have you been!?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm freezing. He goes into the bedroom and takes off the coat and gets dressed as Alex watches in amazement.  David is excited, even euphoric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex, I've lost my mind.  I woke up at the zoo!  But you know what?  I feel terrific!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The zoo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waking up at the zoo, that's not so insane.  Having no clothes on?  That's insane. What did I do last night, Alex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said goodbye to you.  I was locked out of the flat.  I climbed the wall and came in through the bathroom window. I started to read and then I was naked at the zoo! (big smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I am out of my fucking mind. Alex sits next to him and puts her arm around his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I worried about you.  We didn't know where you were. David kisses her, a desperate kiss, and she kisses back with equal passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get that coat? David laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hirsch is dialing the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it. Alex goes to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? The telephone conversation is intercut between Alex and Dr. Hirsch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex, have you heard anything? Alex speaks softly so that David won't hear her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he all right?  Why didn't you call me?  Where was he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't remember.  He woke up at the zoo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The zoo?  Is he rational?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he is.  He's very excited and confused, but he's not crazy, if that's what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you read the papers today?  Have you listened to the radio or television?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is David acting strangely?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not really. Dr. Hirsch considers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you get here without any trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I should think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  Now listen carefully. I want you to bring David here.  I want him in my care. I'll notify the police that we've found him.  It is imperative that you bring him straight to the hospital.  Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're certain he's lucid? You won't need any help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's fine.  We'll come right over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I send a car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, a cab will be faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expect you shortly. Dr. Hirsch hangs up, checks a piece of paper, and then dials again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Scotland Yard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex and David are walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next corner we can get a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should be committed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hirsch will know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stretches)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why I feel so good.  I haven't felt this good in a long time. Alex is signaling for a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My body feels alive, alert.  I feel like an athlete. A taxi pulls up; Alex opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saint Martin's Hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. As they drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like the days of the Mad Barber of Fleet Street, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The murders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What murders?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night.  Haven't you heard?  Six people in different parts of the city mutilated.  A real maniac this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (adamant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab pulls to the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay the man. David gets out of the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, wait! She hurriedly hands the Driver some money and takes off after David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six people mutilated?  It had to be me, Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, stop! He turns and faces her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am going to the cops. There's a full moon tonight. Jack was right.  I....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is dead.  Look, six people have been killed.  I'm going to the police. David takes off walking briskly down the street.  Alex has to jog to keep up with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, please be rational. Let's go to Dr. Hirsch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rational!?!  I'm a fucking werewolf, for Christ's sake! He strides up to a Bobbie on the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer, I killed those people last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interested)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did, did you? Alex runs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's playing a stupid joke, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dumbfounded)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had an argument.  He's being silly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperate)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear, I don't know this girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you two, move along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you asshole!  I want you to arrest me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no call for that kind of language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queen Elizabeth is a man! Prince Charles is a faggot! Winston Churchill was full of shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (losing patience)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now see here young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare was French!  The Queen Mother sucks cocks in hell!  Shit!  Fuck!  Piss! The Bobbie takes David's arm roughly as pedestrians start to gather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's quite enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to have to stop this disturbance or I shall arrest you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated, yelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I want you to do, you moron!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bobbie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, he's very upset.  His friend was killed and....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you shut up!?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (losing his temper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough!  Now go about your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, David, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disbelief)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to arrest me? David approaches one of the ONLOOKERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think he should arrest me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not sure.  How does he know this isn't a prank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (despair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A prank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David.... The Bobbie has lost all patience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've no time for this foolishness. (to onlookers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing to look at.  Move along. The Bobbie walks away.  David is beside himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopeless.  It's hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, let's go now. David turns in a rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone, dammit!  You people are crazy!  I've got to get away from here!  I've got to do something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, don't lose control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaching, hysteria)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Control!?!  What control!?! Get away from me! He begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone! He runs out into the street.  Cars slam on their brakes, just missing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, wait! It's too late.  He's lost in traffic.  Alex stands for a moment not knowing which way to turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is running in panic.  He finally comes to rest in an alley.  He sits down and sobs uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex sits distraught in the chair opposite the desk. Dr. Hirsch is talking to Lt. Villiers and Sgt. McManus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The forensic lads seem to feel that some sort of animal was involved, that's true, but I hardly think....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regardless of what you think, Lieutenant, the fact remains that David is missing and that we must find him. SGT. McMANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before nightfall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precisely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, please.  We shall find Mr. Kessler as quickly as we're able.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tried to have himself arrested.  He....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting arrested isn't all that difficult, Miss Price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants help.  He....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can we do to assist you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here.  If we need you, we'll know where to reach you. He and Sgt. McManus pause by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot accept a connection between David Kessler and last night's murders.  We will find him, however.  I can assure you of that. SGT. McMANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll find him, not to worry. The two policemen exit.  Dr. Hirsch looks at Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distraught)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What shall we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comforting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is in a telephone booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, operator.  I'd like to call the United States and reverse the charges.  David Kessler for anyone.  Yes, I'll wait.  Hello?  Yes, area code 315/472-3402.  Thank you. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?  Rachel?  Just say yes, you'll accept the charges. Just say yes, Rachel.  Is Mom or Dad home?  Where are they? Where's Max?  You're all alone?  Mom and Dad wouldn't leave me alone when I was ten. No, not ten and a half either. I'm still in London.  I'm all better.  Look, would you tell Mom and Dad that I love them? I don't care, Rachel, just do it for me.  Okay?  Good.  And, Rachel, don't fight with Max. Well, try.  Look, kid, please don't forget to tell Mom and Dad I love them.  I love Max and you, too.  Well, I do. No, I'm not being weird, you little creep.  You promise? Okay.  Be a good girl.  I love you.  Bye. He hangs up in profound depression.  Leaving the booth he sees an outdoor clock.  It is 4:15.  He sighs, then catches sight of something. 81   EXT. CINEMA - DAY - DAVID'S P.O.V. There stands Jack, now truly rotted and ghastly.  He's pretty much dried out, a third of his face gone revealing the grinning skull.  He waves to David.  Jack points inside the theater and goes in.  David smiles, walks across the intersection, and up to the box office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two and a half quid, please. David reaches in his pocket.  All he has are traveler's checks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you take a traveler's check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sorry. David signs a $100 check and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep the change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thank you, sir! She gives him a ticket.  David goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A film (to be determined) plays on screen.  The small theater is mostly empty.  A few snoring BUMS and wide- eyed CHILDREN are scattered about.  Jack sits in the last row in the shadows.  He waves to David.  David goes and sits next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, David. They sit for a while watching the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I say, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to say, `I told you so'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I was still alive, I probably would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologizes quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean it.  I don't know what I'm saying.  I'm not even sure it was me who killed those people.  I don't remember doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the zoo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, even if I'm not the wolfman, I am crazy enough to do something like that.  I mean, here I sit in Leicester Square talking to a corpse. I'm glad to see you, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to meet some people. Sitting down the row from Jack is a man, GERALD BRINGSLY, completely in the shadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Kessler, this is Gerald Bringsly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerald is the man you murdered in the subway.  We thought it best you didn't see him as he's a fresh kill and still pretty messy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in shadow; very English)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do look most unpleasant. The camera pans down to show the blood dripping from the seat to a puddle on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this to me, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't Mr. Goodman's idea. He is your good friend, whereas I am a victim of your carnivorous lunar activities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appalled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bringsly, I'm sorry.  I have absolutely no idea what to say to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've left my wife a widow and my children fatherless. And I understand that I am to walk the earth one of the living dead until the wolf's bloodline is severed and the curse lifted. Bringlsy leans forward almost into the light, he glistens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must die, David Kessler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, this is Harry Berman and his fiancee Judith Browns. The two victims lean forward from their seats next to Mr. Bringsly.  We can just make out that Harry has one arm missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And these gentlemen are Alf, Ted, and Joseph. The Three Derelicts sit next to Harry and Judith.  All are slick in the darkness, the light from the screen illuminating their gore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't say we're pleased to meet you, Mr. Kessler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defeated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What shall I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (adamantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must take your own life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's easy for you to say - you're already dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, David.  Harry and I and everyone you murder are not dead.  The undead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because this must be stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How shall I do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleeping pills?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not sure enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could hang myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you did it wrong, it would be painful.  You'd choke to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?  Let `im choke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind?  The man's a friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he ain't no friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where he can get a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't I need a silver bullet or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be serious, would you? David puts his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madness.  I've gone totally mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gun is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just put the gun to your forehead and pull the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you put it in your mouth, then you'd be sure not to miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, you're all so thoughtful. As the conversation continues, the camera pulls back from the grisly tableau.  David grabs his head suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock strikes eleven.  The full moon is up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is dripping wet and shaking violently.  Three small children, the oldest nine, stand in the aisle staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasps out in anguish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away!  Please!  Go away! The children watch, fascinated as David's seizures grow more severe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his face contorting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run!  Please...run. His hands clutch the arms of his chair.  Coarse thick hair splits his skin.  The children's eyes widen in fascination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roars and screams come from inside the theater.  The TICKET TAKER at the door says to the Ticket Lady:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll check on the house. He goes inside the theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ticket Taker enters the theater.  The movie continues on screen, but all else is quiet.  He cautiously continues down the aisle.  He sees something and makes his way towards it.  He looks down in horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From way up high we look down on the sidewalks and single out TWO BOBBIES running furiously to the cinema through the busy traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two cops run up, the Ticket Lady is hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's horrible, horrible! There's a beast!  A mad dog! It's killing people in there! One cop stays with the lady, the other rushes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop enters a side door to find several bloodied corpses.  He hears something, looks over to see the Wolf hunched over a victim.  The Wolf turns, eyes blazing, mouth dripping with blood.  We see it clearly for the first time.  It is truly a hound from hell, its wolfen features a hideous sight.  Its eyes fierce, burning green.  The Wolf roars and starts for the cop. The cop rushes out and slams the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the cop bolts the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake, Tom, there's a monster in there! The doors shudder as the Wolf begins to batter them down.  The cops strain to keep them shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call for assistance and tell them to bring guns. Pedestrians start milling around.  The door is bulging. The Wolf's roars continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep moving!  Will you people get out of the way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is asleep.  Dr. Hirsch wakes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse Hobbs said there's a disturbance in Leicester Square involving some sort of mad dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it.  But it's something to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An officer unlocks a rack of rifles which are distributed to uniformed men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police cars arrive, sirens blaring.  Officers are pushing the crowd back as other men help hold the door closed against the Wolf's battering. Another police car pulls up and out steps Lt. Villiers and Sgt. McManus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's some kind of animal, sir. We.... Suddenly the doors splinter apart and there stands the Wolf, eyes blazing.  It leaps on Lt. Villiers, savaging him.  The crowd falls back in panic. The Wolf runs into traffic, a cab swerves to avoid hitting it and plows into fleeing pedestrians hurling one through a shop window.  Mass confusion as orders are shouted and the police pursue the Wolf. It runs down an alleyway into a cul de sac.  It stops in the darkness, blocked by a brick wall.  The Wolf whirls around, defiant, roaring.  The cops quickly barricade the entrance to the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi is halted by the traffic jam in Leicester Square.  Police vehicles roar past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David!  It's David! She jumps from the car before Dr. Hirsch can stop her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police arrive with weapons and efficiently ring the alley.  Alex runs to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me through!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand clear, miss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must get through! Alex dodges the cop and runs into the alley.  The officers shout after her.  Dr. Hirsch reaches the police line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex! Alex walks towards the dark end of the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David?  Is it you?  Is it true, David? She's almost to the end.  The Wolf lays in wait in the shadows.  The police raise their weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David? THE WOLF REARS UP.  In that brief instant, Alex realizes it will kill her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire! The guns blaze.  The Wolf falls dead.  Alex leans on the wall, numb.  The cops, Dr. Hirsch, and Sgt. McManus run to the dead Wolf only to find David, naked and riddled with bullets.  Alex begins to weep.

dialogues.speaker: END CREDITS OVER BLACK
dialogues.text: SONG: The fifties rock version of "Blue Moon".
